Title: Introduction
SubText1: Welcome to the General William Jenkins Worth Monument.  Located in Manhattan at the intersections of Broadway, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, I was drawn to the site because I have lived and worked within walking distance of it for thirty-plus years but discovered (as part of my team’s initial research) that it is one of only two public memorials in New York City that contain the actual remains of the person.  [The second is President Grant’s Tomb in upper Manhattan.]
SubText2: Having ignored the site for so long, I spent an afternoon watching it and noticed that ignoring the monument was the dominant behavior of almost all the people who walked by it.  That experience led me to ask why?  What was it about the site made it almost disappear into the streetscape?  And why had the memory of the man himself seemingly faded from common knowledge?

SubText1: Memorials in general, and war memorials in particular, are highly social publicly-curated creations that endeavor to fix in time a way of thinking about a person or event.  War memorials are both a way to commemorate a conflict and a way to remember the people involved in that conflict.  In modern times, they often emphasize the common person who served and died as a result of the conflict; consider the Vietnam Memorial in Washington, DC [https://www.nps.gov/vive/index.htm] with its V-shaped black granite wall that lists the names of the dead.  But in ancient times, these memorials were more likely to be victory celebrations around successful military campaigns; consider the Arch of Constantine in Rome [https://www.thebyzantinelegacy.com/constantine-arch], which was built in 312 A.D. to commemorate that Roman emperor’s victory “over Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge in 312 as well as to celebrate his decennalia” (Britannica).
SubText2:
The Worth Memorial is meant to remember the man
but is dominated by the names of places where he fought, and these places are directly
tied to the expansion of the United States into Florida and Mexico in the mid-eighteen
hundreds.
